section.title: Introduction
section.para: Rate limiting is the process of controlling the amount of HTTP requests that are allowed to hit your service per a configurable time period. You can use Repose's rate limiting filter to manage the flow of traffic into your service so that it does not exceed the service's actual capacity. In addition to allowing you to manage legitimate workloads, this allows you to prevent overload due to abuse of your system.

section.title: What Can Repose Rate Limiting Do?
section.para: To understand how Repose handles rate limiting, you must understand the relationship between Repose and an origin service. An origin service is the service for which Repose is performing a function. For example, if Repose is used to provide rate limiting to a load-balancing service, then the load-balancing service is Repose's origin service. Requests are sent to Repose as the proxy for the origin service, not to the server where the origin service lives. Repose functions as a reverse proxy, in that it acts on behalf of the origin service rather than on behalf of the client. Repose passes client requests to the origin service only after those requests have been examined and processed by the Repose filters configured for that origin service.

Repose's rate limiting filter protects the origin service from being bombarded by client requests. It accomplishes this by specifying limits for the number of times a client may request a given resource. When a client has exceeded the number of requests permitted during the current time period, no further requests from that client are delivered to the origin service until a new time period begins. This provides essential protection to any public-facing API.

A client's current limits may include the client's absolute limits. Absolute limits are specific to a service domain and are therefore only provided by the origin service. However, Repose will integrate absolute and current limits as they apply to a client. Repose does not enforce absolute limits, but it does inform the origin service of those limits.

The Repose Rate Limiting filter performs two categories of behavior:
Querying for Limits
Tracking Limits

section.title: Rate Limiting Request Prerequisites
section.para: You must use one of the Identity filters in front of the Rate limiting filters in order to set the required X-PP-User header. In addition, if you support percent-encoded or URL encoded entities, you must use the URI Normalization filter in front of the Identity filter.

section.title: Identity Filter to Set X-PP-User
section.para: To correctly rate limit a requested resource, the rate limiting component uses one required HTTP header precondition and one optional HTTP header precondition.

td.para: X-PP-User is a single-value header. This header is used to describe the unique name of the client making the request. This name is used in part to cache and store request hits.
X-PP-Groups is a list of string values. This header is used to describe all of the limit groups the client belongs to. A client may belong to multiple limit groups or to none.

section.para: These headers are used by the Rate Limiting filter but are populated by other Repose components such as the Authentication filter.

Repose filters may add values to HTTP message headers to communicate a set of options to downstream filters. To aid downstream filters in selecting the most qualified value from a given set, the values themselves may be annotated with a quality factor parameter. This allows downstream filters to make a decision based on the available options rather then on which filter overwrote the header last.

section.title: URL Normalization Filter for Percent-encoded URLs
section.para: If you support URI encoded entities such as the following paths:

listitem.para: /servers/abc/instances/123
/servers/abc/instances/%31%32%33

section.para: you need to use the URI Normalization filter in front of the Rate Limiting filter. Percent encoded URLs will fail to be properly rate limited unless normalized by the URI Normalization filter.

section.title: Configuration Options
section.para: Configure the Rate Limiting filter by editing the rate-limiting.cfg.xml file and specifying the headers to be normalized. Add the filter to the Repose deployment through the System Model Configuration by editing the following elements and attributes:

listitem.para: <rate-limiting>: uses the accompanying sub-elements and attributes to define your rate limiting configuration.

datastore (optional): stores rate limiting information. If not specified, rate limiting will use the first distributed datastore available. If no distributed datastores are available, it will revert to using a local datastore. Valid values are local/default, distributed/hash-ring (requires dist-datastore service), and distributed/replicated (requires replicated-datastore filter).

note.para: If the rate limiting filter is configured to use the distributed datastore, and the distributed datastore service is unable to communicate with other nodes (e.g., during a rolling upgrade to Repose) , the distributed datastore service will fall back on the local datastore. As a result, rate limits may not be tracked correctly (limits cannot be retrieved from damaged nodes, and are created fresh on the local datastore).

listitem.para: datastore-warn-limit (optional): defines <limit> in order to log a warning on size when an object is stored in the database over this limit. When the limit is met, Repose will issue a warning message in the logs. The limit default is 1000 cache keys per user.

overLimit-429-responseCode (optional): when set to true, will send a 429 response code instead of the default 413 response code. The 429 response code in conjunction with the Response Messaging Service Configuration will provide a custom over-limit message.

use-capture-groups (optional): when is set to false, it will count all the requests with the <uri-regex> that have the capture group towards the limit count specified. By default, this attribute is set to true. If it is set to false, the first rate limit with a uri-regex that matches the request URI will be used to apply the rate limit.

<request-endpoint> (recommended) : This element sets the endpoint and format with which the user can query limits. It must specify a regular expression that identifies client requests for the client's current limits. This element is highly recommended, but it is not required. If the request-endpoint element is not in the configuration, the user cannot query limits.

uri-regex: the regular expression (regex) used to match a passing request to the current limit group. Within the regex, each capture group is allowed the number of requests specified in the value attribute of the limit element.
uri: defines a human-readable URI describing the endpoint for a given configured limit.
include-absolute-limits: enables or disables integration with absolute limits.
<limit-group> : defines a list of rate limits to be applied to a user, based on the user's membership in a group.
id: defines the unique identifier for a given limit group.
groups: defines a space-delimited list of the groups to which this limit group will apply.
default: identifies the limit group that will be applied if a user is passed if either no group is specified or no group in the rate limiting configuration matches the group or groups specified.
<limit> : describes limits configured for a given endpoint.
http-methods: lists the HTTP methods associated with this limit. Valid values include: GET, DELETE, POST, PUT, HEAD, OPTIONS, CONNECT, TRACE, ALL.
unit: defines the unit of time associated with this limit. Valid values include: SECOND, MINUTE, HOUR, DAY.
value: defines the number of requests allowed within the configured unit of time.

para.guilabel: Your rate limiting configuration in rate-limiting.cfg.xml will resemble the following example:

programlistingco.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<rate-limiting xmlns="http://docs.rackspacecloud.com/repose/rate-limiting/v1.0"> <request-endpoint uri-regex="/service/limits/" include-absolute-limits="true"/>
<limit-group id="customer-limits " groups="customer" default="true"> <limit uri="/service/*" uri-regex="/service/([\d^/]*)/.*" http-methods="GET" unit="SECOND" value="1"/> <limit uri="/service/*" uri-regex="/service/([\d^/]*)/.*" http-methods="DELETE" unit="MINUTE" value="5"/> <limit uri="/service/*" uri-regex="/service/([\d^/]*)/.*" http-methods="PUT" unit="HOUR" value="15"/> <limit uri="/service/*" uri-regex="/service/([\d^/]*)/.*" http-methods="POST" unit="DAY" value="2"/> </limit-group>
<limit-group id="admin-limits" groups="admin"> <limit uri="/service/admin/*" uri-regex="/service/admin/(.*)" http-methods="GET POST PUT DELETE" unit="SECOND" value="1"/> </limit-group> </rate-limiting>

section.para: Key elements of the preceding example are labeled with callouts and explained below:

callout.para: The request-endpoint configuration element must specify a regular expression that identifies client requests for the client's current limits.
This element is highly recommended, but it is not required. If the request-endpoint element is not in the configuration, the user cannot query limits.

The uri-regex attribute of the request-endpoint configuration element must be a regular expression. It should match all representations of the request resource that the rate limiting component should answer.
The include-absolute-limits attribute of the request-endpoint configuration element is a Boolean attribute that can be used to switch on or off integration with the origin service's absolute limits.
One or more specifications of limit-group may be associated with a single specification of request-endpoint.
Limit groups identify a group of related rate limits and bind them to a series of names. The names can be used to limit incoming requests using the X-PP-Groups header.
An id uniquely identifies each limit-group.
Specifying groups for a limit-group associates it with recognizable workloads. In this example, one limit-group relates to customers and another relates to administrators.

A single limit-group may be identified as the default group. The default group will handle any requests that cannot be matched on the basis of a group name to any of the groups identified in the X-PP-Groups header. In this example, the limits defined for groups="customer" will be applied to requests that cannot be explicitly matched to a group.
The uri attribute defines a human-readable descriptive name for this limit.

section.title: Rate Limiting Behavior
section.para:
There are two general categories of behavior performed by the Repose rate limiting component:
Querying for Limits
Tracking Limits

section.title: Querying Limits
section.para: This feature allows the client to view how many requests a user has already sent and how the Rate Limiting filter behaves.

The Rate Limiting Filter caches rate limits by user. Consequently, to query limits, a user must be passed into the rate limiting component. The rate limiting component uses the X-PP-User header to identify the user whose limits will be queried. Without a value in this header, the rate limiting component will send back a "401 Unauthorized".

The rate limiting component uses the X-PP-Groups header to determine which rate limits to apply to the user. Without this header present, the rate limiting component will assign limits from a default group specified in the rate-limiting.cfg.xml configuration file.

It is possible to query a user's rate limits before the user's limits are placed in the cache. This is the case when querying limits before the user has ever been rate limited. In this case, there are two possible results based on the contents of the X-PP-Groups header:

listitem.para: If the X-PP-Groups header containing specification of a group is passed in, then the rate limits configured for the specified group in rate-limiting.cfg.xml are returned.
If the X-PP-Groups header is not passed in, then the rate limits configured for the default limit group in rate-limiting.cfg.xml are returned.

section.para: As shown below, a request in which the user is identified via X-PP-User and the user's group is identified via X-PP-Groups generates a response showing all the limits applicable to that user in that group:

table.caption: Sample Request/Response Conversation: Request Limits for User

td.literallayout: GET /service/limits HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/vnd.rackspace-v1.0+xml X-PP-User: demo-username X-PP-Groups: demo-customer

td.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<limits xmlns="http://docs.openstack.org/common/api/v1.0"> <rates> <rate uri="/service*" regex="/service/([\d^/]*)/.*"> <limit value="5" verb="DELETE" unit="MINUTE" remaining="1" next-available="2010-12-15T22:42:12Z" /> <limit value="15" verb="PUT" unit="HOUR" remaining="4" next-available="2010-12-15T22:42:12Z" /> <limit value="2" verb="POST" unit="DAY" remaining="1" next-available="2010-12-15T22:42:12Z" /> </rate> </rates> </limits>

note.para: The rate limiting component understands quality factors for the X-PP-User and X-PP-Groups headers. This is useful when a service implementer wishes to employ multiple authentication/identity mechanisms. You can learn more about how Repose handles authentication and identity in the Repose Authentication and Authorization Components Deployment Handbook.

If multiple user or group values are present in the X-PP-User or X-PP-Groups headers with the same quality, then the first value is used. If the user or group does not have an explicit quality, Repose assumes the quality for that item is 1.

section.para: In the rate limiting configuration shown below, rate-limiting.cfg.xml defines limits to be applied to two groups, BETA_Group and IP_Standard, and separately defines limits to be applied to default group named My_Group. The limits defined for My_Group apply when no other group is specified. In the request-endpoint element, which applies to all groups, the uri-regex attribute is set to /limits. This is the URI at which the user should query for rate limits.

example.title: Rate Limiting Configuration with Default Group
example.programlisting:
<rate-limiting xmlns="http://docs.rackspacecloud.com/repose/rate-limiting/v1.0"> <request-endpoint uri-regex="/limits" include-absolute-limits="false" />
<limit-group id="limited" groups="BETA_Group IP_Standard" default="false"> <limit uri="*" uri-regex="/something/(.*)" http-methods="PUT" unit="MINUTE" value="10" /> <limit uri="*" uri-regex="/something/(.*)" http-methods="GET" unit="MINUTE" value="10" /> </limit-group>
<limit-group id="limited-all" groups="My_Group" default="true"> <limit uri="*" uri-regex="/something/(.*)" http-methods="ALL" unit="HOUR" value="10" /> </limit-group> </rate-limiting>

section.para: Under this rate limiting configuration, a request in which the user is not yet in the cache generates a response showing the limits applicable to that user on the basis of the default group:

table.caption: Sample Request/Response Conversation: Request Limits for User Not in Cache

informalexample.programlisting: <limits xmlns="http://docs.openstack.org/common/api/v1.0"> <rates> <rate regex="/something/(.*)" uri="*"> <limit next-available="2012-06-22T14:39:33.832Z" unit="HOUR" remaining="10" value="10" verb="ALL"/> </rate> </rates> </limits>

section.para: Under the same rate limiting configuration, a request associating a user with a group generates a response showing the limits applicable to that user on the basis of membership in the IP_Standard group:

table.caption: Sample Request/Response Conversation: Request Limits for User in Group

informalexample.programlisting: <limits xmlns="http://docs.openstack.org/common/api/v1.0"> <rates> <rate regex="/something/(.*)" uri="*"> <limit next-available="2012-06-22T15:38:17.956Z" unit="MINUTE" remaining="10" value="10" verb="PUT"/> <limit next-available="2012-06-22T15:38:17.956Z" unit="MINUTE" remaining="10" value="10" verb="GET"/> </rate> </rates> </limits>

section.title: Tracking Limits
section.para: This feature tracks the number of requests a user has within a timetable defined by the rate limiting configuration. The Rate Limiting filter tracks limits by decrementing all rate-limits which match the request URI and the verb as shown in the example below. To track limits, specify a POST to /servers .
Repose shares limits across nodes using the Distributed Datastore service. Look here for more information about setting up the Distributed Datastore service for use with the Rate Limiting filter.

section.title: Set Up Distributed Rate Limiting
section.para: Repose shares limits across nodes using the Distributed Datastore Service. You can implement distributed rate limiting with Repose by adding the Distributed Datastore service with the Rate Limiting filter.

procedure.title: To set up distributed rate limiting:

step.para: Configure Repose using a cluster configuration (multiple servers). Note that all servers must use the same system model.
Add the Rate Limiting filter to your system model configuration.
Add the Distributed Datastore service to your system model configuration.

section.title: Handling Limited Client Requests
section.para: When a client makes a request that exceeds the client's specified rate limit, the rate limiting component will return the HTTP response code 413 (Request Entity Too Large).
When this occurs, the response's Retry-After HTTP header contains HTTP-encoded data that the client can use to plan a retry.

td.programlisting: GET /service/my/resource HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/vnd.rackspace-v1.0+xml X-PP-User: username X-PP-Groups: customer
HTTP/1.1 413 Request Entity Too Large Retry-After: Thu, 30 Jun 2011 20:24:39 GMT

section.title: Rate Limiting Filter Order
section.para: In order to rate limit by certain mechanisms you need to configure the proper identity filter before the rate limiting filter in your system model. The examples below show the necessary order of the filters.
Rate Limit by User:
Client-auth filter <filter name= "client-auth"/>
Rate Limiting filter <filter name ="rate-limiting/>
URI- identity filter <filter name= "uri-identity"/>
Rate Limiting filter <filter name= "rate-limiting"/>
Header-Identity Filter <filter name="header-identity"/>
Rate Limiting Filter <filter name= "rate-limiting"/>
